instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .

threads.title: LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B green light no boot no chime no charge
threads.message: So , i have a 2011 15" macbook pro with good one wire circuit, good s5 rail, seem to have all the rails I am supposed to except it won't charge a known good battery or turn on.

threads.title: LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B green light no boot no chime no charge
threads.message:
Good S5 rail... which rail?

What rails are present?

Which rails are not?

Are S5 rails present but not S3? Are S5 and S3 present but not S0? Are S5/S3/S0 present but one S0 rail is missing? 

More info!

threads.title: LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B green light no boot no chime no charge
threads.message: [SIZE=16px]<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> are good, have not found any S3 or SO rails[/SIZE]

threads.message: this was water damage??? Check <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R1801</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R1802</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R1803</RESISTOR>, should have about 3.3V on each pin, also check 32Kz from <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>.....

threads.title: LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B green light no boot no chime no charge
threads.message:
All The resistors are fine and chowing the 3.3v. I am not sure how to measure the 32Kz from <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>
There is no evidence of liquid damage on the board

threads.title: LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B green light no boot no chime no charge
threads.message: and we have our first <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> rabbit hole to hell.. do you have a lot of time to spend on something that is most likely not fixable? :X I'll leave this one for duke

threads.title: LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B green light no boot no chime no charge
threads.message: Of course, I seem to get the good ones! Why can't i get the ones with obvious liquid damage around the ISL chip, replace a couple of components and boom! Back in business. Oh, well.....

threads.title: LB <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B green light no boot no chime no charge
threads.message: Unless duke has some thoughts I will probably just move on.  I have another 13" 2010 MacBook Pro that is randomly sleeping while you use it. I will probably start a new topic on that one soon.
